justification: The manuscript states: "Self-reported depressive symptoms – The total score of the Beck Depression Inventory-II (Beck et al., 1996)".
It describes using the "Five-Facets Mindfulness Questionnaire (FFMQ)" listing the Observe, Describe, Acting with Awareness, Non-Judging and Non-Reactivity facets that respondents rate.
The article notes: "Self-Compassion Scale (SCS; Neff, 2003) – The SCS consists of six self-compassion subscale factors…".

topic_or_construct: dispositional positive emotions (e.g., Joy, Contentment, Love)
justification: Under DPES it says: "Dispositional Positive Emotion Scale (DPES; Shiota et al., 2006)… we included the subscales Joy, Contentment, Love, Compassion and Awe."

The methods section lists the "Cognitive Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (CERQ; Garnefski et al., 2001)" which "assesses individuals' propensity to employ four maladaptive and five adaptive emotion regulation strategies".
It states: "Cambridge-Exeter Repetitive Thought Scale (CERTS; Barnard et al., 2007) – The CERTS assesses individuals' dispositional tendency for Brooding … and repetitive thinking in general."
The text notes: "Measure of Parental Style (MOPS; Parker et al., 1997) was administered to assess levels of parental abuse experienced as a child."
"General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSE; Schwarzer et al., 1995) – The GSE is a ten-item scale that assessed individuals' sense of self-efficacy over the past two week period."
Under Bespoke measures: "Stigmatization and Normalization (SN) was a bespoke 7-item questionnaire asking individuals to indicate how often they experienced stigmatization due to their depression."

topic_or_construct: ability to recognize warning signs of depression
justification: "Warning Signs (WS) was a bespoke 6-item questionnaire assessing individuals' ability to recognize warning signs of depression."
The article states: "Relationship Satisfaction (RS) was assessed with a bespoke questionnaire… the scale's 7 items assess relationship satisfaction."

During model building they used "baseline symptom severity on the clinician-assessed Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HAMD; Hamilton, 1967) assessed using the 17-item GRID-HAMD (Williams et al., 2008)."
Relapse outcome was determined as "a return of depressive symptoms meeting DSM-IV criteria (as assessed via Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV)" during follow-up.
